essays.title: On Friendship
essays.author: Michel de Montaigne
essays.why: Montaigne's warm meditation on friendship explores loyalty, intimacy, and the rare bond of a perfect companion.

essays.title: Walking
essays.author: Henry David Thoreau
essays.why: A celebration of nature and the freedom of the open air, Thoreau’s essay invites readers to rediscover the wild around them.

essays.title: The Philosophy of Style
essays.author: Herbert Spencer
essays.why: Spencer examines clarity and force in writing, offering timeless advice for anyone who wants their words to resonate.

essays.title: On the Pleasure of Hating
essays.author: William Hazlitt
essays.why: Hazlitt reflects on human contradictions and the strange satisfaction we find in dislike, with sharp wit and honesty.

essays.title: Dream-Children: A Reverie
essays.author: Charles Lamb
essays.why: A tender, bittersweet essay on family, memory, and the power of imagination, blending gentle humor with quiet sorrow.

essays.title: The Decay of Lying
essays.author: Oscar Wilde
essays.why: Wilde playfully defends artifice and imagination over dull reality, making a spirited case for the beauty of fiction.

essays.title: On Being Idle
essays.author: Jerome K. Jerome
essays.why: A humorous defense of doing nothing, celebrating leisure and the art of taking life lightly.

essays.title: The Book of Tea
essays.author: Kakuzo Okakura
essays.why: A graceful meditation on tea culture, aesthetics, and Eastern philosophy, blending art and spirituality.

essays.title: An Apology for Idlers
essays.author: Robert Louis Stevenson
essays.why: Stevenson argues for the value of leisure and unstructured time as essential to a full and observant life.

essays.title: On the Shortness of Life
essays.author: Seneca
essays.why: A Stoic classic reminding us that life is long enough—if we spend it wisely and with purpose.
